docs.lead_paragraph: Lurking in the guts of many pets and people is a sneaky parasite that may well be the most common cause of gastrointestinal distress in this and many other countries. The organism, a protozoan called giardia (pronounced jee-AR-dee-ya), is easy to acquire but hard to diagnose and often difficult to treat effectively. It can cause no symptoms at all or it can turn its host into one sick puppy suffering from abdominal cramps, diarrhea and weight loss. It may even result in food allergies. In its various forms, giardia can infect most vertebrates, but one form, Giardia lamblia, has a particular penchant for mammals, including dogs, cats, livestock and people.

headline.main: Sly Parasite Menaces Pets and Their Owners

docs.lead_paragraph: My grandmother lived vigorously to the age of 100. She was raised in an impoverished shtetl in czarist Russia, arrived in America the day McKinley was shot, lived in a cold-water tenement, sewed garments in a crowded, filthy sweatshop and delivered four children at home. I always assumed she carried genes for longevity and a strong constitution. There were some in her family, similarly healthy and long-lived, who inherited those genes, and others, less blessed, who did not. It was a matter of good fortune, and nothing fundamental could be done to alter the outcome. Yet as we look into the next century, we see science poised to determine a person's life span directly, by modifying his genes. Pills would replace parents as the key to vigorous longevity. Although providing long and healthy lives is a laudable goal, the consequences of this approach raise deeply disturbing questions.
docs.abstract: Prof Jerome Groopman article on longevity notes science is poised to determine person's life span directly by genetic engineering; says even though providing long and healthy lives is laudable goal, consequences of approach raise deeply disturbing ethical questions; diagram (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Warren Wegele is on the front line of a medical revolution. After doing a simple blood test recently, doctors at the University of Cincinnati Medical Center told Mr. Wegele, a 65-year-old former salesman for air compressor companies, that he had inherited a tiny alteration in one of his genes. A certain chemical unit out of the string of three billion that make up the mass of DNA in his cells is different from the norm.

headline.main: Using Gene Tests to Customize Medical Treatment

docs.abstract: Genetic testing is being used to identify patients who will benefit from certain drugs, patients who will not and patients who will suffer troubling side effects; experts predict that the first application of such testing will be for more common diseases like asthma, arthritis, heart disease, high blood pressure and migraines, but that it will eventually be applied to virtually any drug for any disease; drug companies believe that drug prices could increase, but say that drugs will be so much more effective that they will be worth more to patients; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S the holiday season, and you're too busy sipping eggnog, wrapping presents to tying up loose ends at the office to spend much time with year-end personal financial matters. That's fine - you probably won't need to do a millennial reconstruction of your finances anyway. But minor changes in tax law, the volatile financial markets and the coming of the Year 2000 may call for some adjustments and precautions. Here are some suggestions from experts. JAN M. ROSEN with KATHLEEN O'BRIEN YEAR 2000 What to Do

headline.main: Personal Business; Housecleaning, Before the Party

byline.original: By Jan M. Rosen and Kathleen O'Brien

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders from both major parties agreed today to raise the state's cigarette tax by 55 cents a pack in an ambitious effort to provide health care coverage for as many as one million uninsured New Yorkers. Mr. Pataki and leaders of the Legislature also decided to renew a program that pays hospitals about $1.3 billion a year to train new doctors and treat poor people who show up in their emergency rooms with no way of paying their bills. The program had been set to expire at the end of the year, threatening the state's health care system with financial uncertainty.

headline.main: NEW YORK RAISING TAX ON CIGARETTES TO HELP UNINSURED

docs.abstract: Gov George E Pataki and legislative leaders from both parties agree to raise state cigarette tax by 55 cents a pack in ambitious effort to provide health care coverage for as many as one million uninsured New Yorkers; also decide to renew program that pays hospitals about $1.3 billion a year to train new doctors and treat poor people who show up in emergency rooms with no way of paying their bills; plan to expand coverage for the uninsured would be financed with revenue from added cigarette tax, state's share of national tobacco settlement and new federal health care funds; charts of cigarette prices and taxes in New York City, New York State and other states (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Calling the nation's health care system ''too costly, too inaccessible and too bureaucratic,'' Senator John McCain today set out a plan of ''tailored reforms'' that included a federal program to help the low-income elderly pay for prescription drugs and a limited right to sue health maintenance organizations. Mr. McCain's plan, offered in a speech to the Charleston Rotary Club, was part of an effort to capitalize on his surge in New Hampshire by fleshing out his positions on issues. Health care -- and most particularly the soaring costs of prescription drugs -- has emerged as one of the hottest topics on the campaign trail this year, and until now it has been a policy arena largely dominated by the Democrats.

headline.main: McCain Unveils HealthPlan Calling for Modest Changes

docs.abstract: Republican presidential candidate Sen John McCain, in speech to Charleston Rotary Club in South Carolina, says nation's health care system is too costly, too inaccessible and too bureaucratic and sets out plan of 'tailored reforms' that includes federal program to help low-income elderly pay for prescription drugs and limited right to sue health maintenance organizations; highlights of plan discussed; photo (M)
